awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Cross-plane and  In-plane Transport in 2D Layered Heterostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this collaborative effort is to develop an understanding of thermal and thermoelectric transport in an important new class of two-dimensional (2D) crystalline materials. This class of materials has the lowest thermal conductivities ever observed in a fully dense material. Highly efficient thermoelectrics can provide efficient solid-state cooling that rivals conventional refrigeration systems. This effort leverages measurement techniques recently developed in the Cronin lab, which enable the cross-plane (i.e. in the direction perpendicular to the layers) thermal and thermoelectric transport of extremely thin films to be measured accurately for the first time, and the unique materials synthesis capabilities developed in the Johnson lab, which enable specific sequences of 2D layers to be prepared and structurally characterized. Together, the labs will address several open questions regarding the thermal and thermoelectric transport properties of this interesting materials system, such as how the arrangement of layers and density of interfaces impact the difference between in plane and cross plane transport properties. 

This proposal will explore thermal and thermoelectric phenomena in a unique class of materials poised between the amorphous and crystalline states and test potential device structures using novel measurement techniques. In addition to thermoelectric energy conversion, the proposed scheme of studying cross-plane transport can be applied to a wide range of other device systems, including LEDs, FETs, and RTDs, currently being investigated by other groups. The proposed heterostructure geometries open up new degrees of freedom in the cross-plane transport with independent control of electrons and phonons, which is essential for achieving efficient thermoelectric energy conversion devices. The proposed layered heterostructures will enable many parameters to be varied such as inter-material barrier height, band gap (across the semiconductor-semimetal spectrum), and charge density wave transitions over a wide range of compositions to optimize thermoelectric phenomena. These structures enable investigation of systematic structural changes that are not possible with traditional approaches, for example, atomically-sharp interfaces that are not lattice matched and metal/semiconductor superlattices with atomically abrupt interfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project synthesized, structurally characterized, and measured the in-plane and cross-plane transport properties of heterostructures containing alternating layers of a metal (VSe2) and either a semiconductor (PbSe) or a magnetic semiconductor (Pb2MnSe3) to understand how the highly anisotropic structure, electrical and magnetic phase transitions, and incoherent interfaces impact charge and heat transport. In-plane thermoelectric transport properties of (PbSe)(VSe2)1 and (PbSe)(VSe2)2 heterostructures revealed an abrupt 86% increase in the Seebeck coefficient, a 245% increase in the power factor, and an increase in resistivity as temperature is decreased through the CDW transition of (PbSe)(VSe2)1. The CDW transition causes a deviation from the Mott relationship through correlated electron states. The 2-lead cross-plane resistivity, corrected for contact resistances measured by in-plane 2- and 4-lead resistivity measurements, is 100,000 times larger than the in-plane resistivity.  (Pb2MnSe3)1+δ(VSe2) was successfully synthesized, structurally characterized, and transport properties measured. The Pb2MnSe3 constituent consists of a distorted 3-layer thick rock salt structure. The middle MnSe layer has a PbSe monlayer on both sides, which is surprising since no bulk ternary Pb-Mn-Se compounds are known. The Mn2+ cations each have four long bonds to Se in the plane and two shorter bonds to the Se in the top and bottom PbSe layers.  The central MnSe layer stabilizes a puckering distortion of the PbSe layers. (Pb2MnSe3)1+δ(VSe2) has a charge density wave transition at ~150K and in addition there is a ferromagnetic transition at 35K due to the ferromagnetic interaction between the high spin Mn2+ cations. 
The synthesis approach used to prepare these metastable heterostructures is compatible with wafer scale coverage and conventional lithography, providing a pathway to using heterostructures in microelectronic devices. The cross-plane measurement techniques developed provides critical information about interface resistances between structurally dissimilar materials, which is linked to the fundamental bonding interactions between materials at interfaces. Since the interfaces in heterostructures are well defined, the information obtained depends on the nanoarchitecture of the heterostructure and the structural and chemical differences between the constituents.
The training of students in thin film materials synthesis and characterization prepares them for careers in high technology industries. Two graduate students supported by this proposal at Oregon are now process engineers with semiconductor manufacturing companies. A third graduate student is currently a post-doctoral researcher.  These graduate students mentored pods of outstanding undergraduate students in an immersion lab experience, which introduced the undergraduates to research, encouraged them to be science majors, and motivated them to continue doing undergraduate research after the immersion lab experience. All the undergraduate students mentored in this program remained science majors and joined research labs.
